Notes: This datatype property can be linked to both record resources and instantiations (e.g. in case a particular copy of a record has a conservation access restriction).
RiC-O also has more specific datatype property rico:accrualsStatus which seems more intended for controlled values.
Not relevant for mapping, since this field doesn't exist in ADD.

Modelling the describing archivist using the class rico:Person involves using rico:Record (i.e. the description) and rico:Activity (i.e. the creation or modification of an archival description). There is also a more complex class-based modelling of the rico:isOrWasPerformedBy relation (i.e. rico:PerformanceRelation) that allows further data to be captured, such as date etc. See examples in RiC-CM section 6.4.
Used for non-public generic notes. Serves same function as Hidden Notes in Listings database.
Has sub-properties rico:instantiationStructure and rico:recordResourceStructure. Not relevant for mapping, since this field doesn't exist in ADD.

Can be enriched using rico:hasGeneticLinktoRecordResource object property to link to another record resource external to the AO with a provenance-based relationship. A super-property for a more generic link is rico:RecordResourcetoRecordResourceRelation, which has several other sub-properties.

Can be enriched by adding links to relevant Instantiations using object properties rico:hasOrHadDigitalInstantiation, rico:hasOrHadAnalogueInstantiation or their super-property rico:hasOrHadInstantiation (among other options).

Links to particular instantiations. Use object property rico:hasIdentifierType and class rico:IdentifierType to indicate that this is a barcode for a physical container. Question: do we want to model this data? A barcode is not unique to a particular instantiation, since many others share the same identifier (in same box).
Not sure if this data is required.
Data in this ADD field will need substantial review.

In the ADD this was an internal field (not public) used to indicate when conservation work had been done. RiC doesn't make this distinction and simply has the rico:physicalCharacteristicsNote datatype property. Any data in the ADD conservation field should be reviewed and mapped accordingly.
Description of physical containers is outside the scope of RiC. However, it is designed to be extensible (see RiC-CM section 1.2). Need to identify appropriate ontology for this.
Use object property rico:hasCreator or rico:hasCollector etc. to link to class rico:Agent or its sub-classes (rico:Person, rico:CorporateBody or rico:Family).
Use object property rico:hasIdentifierType and class rico:IdentifierType to indicate that this is a creator code.
Same field used for immediate source of aquisition (this can be a separate instance).
There is no accumulation equivalent for the simple datatype property rico:creationDate. AH rasied this issue with EGAD on Github and there is agreement in principle to create one in due course.
Use this datatype property to accommodate date ranges in the Dates of Creation field. Can be enriched through use of additonal date classes for specific dates.
TBC - this might be affected by modelling of subject terms. Presumably you would link a subject using rico:hasOrHadSubject and then add links to dates.
In the Description dataset, this field records only the last date of modification (not a complete log of modification dates).
Filing class has been used to group related files in cases where the creation of a sub-series seemed unnecessary for whatever reason. We may want to create a record set type to accommodate this data.

This object property can be used to link a record resource to a record (finding aid) that descibes it. The record can be identified as a finding aid using the class rico:DocumentaryFormType and named individual ric-dft:FindingAid.
This generic datatype property seems the best fit for our finding aid notes, which merely indicate the existence (or not) of finding aids but do not identify a specific finding aid.

This object property can be used to link a record resource to a record (finding aid) that descibes it. The record can be identified as a finding aid using the class rico:DocumentaryFormType and named individual ric-dft:FindingAid.
RiC also has a somewhat related class called rico:DocumentaryFormType, which is used to indicate specific record types (e.g. deed of sale).
Use object property rico:hasIdentifierType and class rico:IdentifierType to indicate that this is a former code.

Use object property rico:isAssociatedWithPlace or more specific sub-properties to link an agent or record resource to a place. Can be extended with various object properties to link to further information about the place.
Used for non-public generic notes. Serves same function as Archivist's Comment in Description database.

Data in this field is used to indicate the reference code of the relevant higher-level record set in the Description database (necessary because of the legacy practice of not consistently including file/item level reference codes).
Linked to the instantiation.
This field was a system requirement of ADD (used to create a link between the Descriptions database and the Visual database) and seems unnecessary in a RiC implementation.
Same field used for custodial history (this can be a separate instance).
Should interloan copies of microfilm be modelled as Availability of Other Formats?
RiC-O has four named instances of this class: ric-rst:Collection; ric-rst:File; ric-rst:Fonds; ric-rst:Series

ADD Data Element: Link to Authority (Private sector records only)
Notes: This field was a system requirement of ADD (used to generate a brief bio and provenance link to authority). The real link to authority is the Provenance field.
This field was a system requirement of ADD (used to create a link between the Descriptions database and the Listings database) and seems unnecessary in a RiC implementation.
This field was a system requirement of ADD (used to create a link between the fonds/series levels and sub-series in the Descriptions database) and seems unnecessary in a RiC implementation.
Use object property rico:hasOrHadSubject to link to class rico:Agent or its sub-classes (rico:Person, rico:CorporateBody or rico:Family). Note: there is also a sub-property rico:hasOrHadMainSubject.
Used for any generic, publicly accessible notes not otherwise accommodated.

ADD Mnemonic: Repeatable group field containing DATEOFF, OFFICEAB, OFFICEC
Notes:
Use object property rico:hasCreator or rico:hasCollector etc. to link to class rico:CorporateBody. NOTE: in order to assign dates to a provenance relation (as we do for government entities in the Office of Origin group of fields), we will need to implement a class-based relation between record resources and agents (see Draw.io diagram).

Also, in RiC-O we should not attempt to model higher-level authority controlling relationships in description models as we do in the ADD field Office of Origin, since that information is part of the authority itself (see Data Decision Log).
Used to indicate the date at which a restricted file/item will become unrestricted. Maybe this data could be added to the rico:conditionsOfAccess literal?
Use a relevant object property to link to class rico:Agent or its sub-classes (rico:Person, rico:CorporateBody or rico:Family). There are many potential links.
Links to particular instantiations. A separate rico:integrityNote datatype property exists for intellectual completeness of a record resource.

Combine ADD instances of Physical Description at every level above item level (in which case there would be a separate Instantiation class for each Instantiation). Note that a seperate class for informational extent exists (rico:RecordResourceExtent), which connects directly to the record resource, not the instantiation.

Use object property rico:hasCreator or rico:hasCollector etc. to link to class rico:Agent or its sub-classes (rico:Person, rico:CorporateBody or rico:Family). NOTE: in order to assign dates to a provenance relation (as we do for government entities in the Office of Origin group of fields, we will need to implement a class-based relation between record resources and agents.
Use object property rico:hasIdentifierType and class rico:IdentifierType to indicate that this is a current (as opposed to former) reference code.

Can be enriched by using rico:hasGeneticLinktoRecordResource object property to link to another record resource internal to the AO with a provenance-based relationship. A super-property for a more generic link is rico:RecordResourcetoRecordResourceRelation, which has several other sub-properties.
Could be extended with a scale sub-property (not available in RiC-O, which only has datatype properties for length, width, height, latitude, longitutde and altitude).
This field was a system requirement of ADD and seems unnecessary in a RiC implementation.

AH asked RiC user group for advice on this. Currently no relevant object property available, but noted for future revision. Meanwhile, rico:generalDescription may be best option. Not relevant for mapping, since this field doesn't exist in ADD.
Used to indicate the approval status of a Description in ADD (statuses include: preliminary, reviewed, approved).
This datatype property can be linked to both record  resources and instantiations (e.g. in case a particular copy of a record has some conditions of use).
RiC-O offers both a class and datatype for this information.
Used to control publication of Descriptions and Listings data on the public-facing OPAC (statuses are Y or N). There is also a rico:hasPublicationDate object property.
